Message.Title: The History lesson I use to remind shorts - Stay the Course!
Message.Msg: In 1998, Ray Dirks, made famous in 1974 for exposing the Equity Funding fraud, wrote a 45 page single spaced report on Conseco in which he offered over 100 detailed reasons Conseco was a $1 stock in a $45 jumpsuit. It seemed rock solid to me. One week after the report, I listened to a CC with perhaps 20 big Wall Street analysts asking questions. The questions were all soft balls. That year, about $200MM just appeared on the balance sheet out of nowhere, and not one person on the CC asked where it came from. Dirks was an Island of One, telling people to run from the stock. 18 months later, Conseco stock was roughly $1. It all comes back to cash flows.

Topic.Title: Living Social could hurt this patent of Local Corp

Message.Msg: Groupon needs for Groupon Now a licensing from Local Corp "Before a company can book a single penny in profit it needs a product to sell. Yet in today’s fiercely competitive global economy, before a company can produce something to sell, it needs to patent the idea. Otherwise, it’s too easy for competitors to knock off the product and steal market share. In other words, being first to market is no longer enough of a competitive advantage. Companies need to be first to market and have patents protecting their products to ensure sales and profit longevity. Groupon (Nasdaq: GRPN) and Apple (Nasdaq: AAPL) serve as good examples of this new paradigm at work. As you’re well aware, Groupon invented the daily deals market in 2008. All it took was a novel idea to connect consumers and businesses in a new way – via coupons over email. But guess what? Groupon didn’t have even one patent protecting its novel business model. And within four years, over 300 competitors emerged. Now, Groupon doesn’t stand a chance to keep booking higher profits, let alone survive. Contrast Groupon’s experience with the details behind the meteoric rise of Apple and you’ll definitely get the connection between patent filings and stock price performance. We can all agree that Apple took the world by storm with its iPhone launch in June 2007. Before it sold a single one, though, it secured as many patents as possible. And it continued to do the same thing on every next generation device." Source: Patent Filings: The Next Great Leading Indicator by Seeking Alpha March 11, 2012

Message.Title: Rating agencies and AMZN bonds
Message.Msg: Bond issuance was great for shareholders when you consider the company was facing a near term liquidity challenge. After paying for the HQ real estate purchase, the company should have roughly $1B in working capital. The Moody's analyst did everything but apologize for the Baa1 rating. It's rare to see an investment grade rating based almost entirely on future potential earnings driven by future market share gains and future new product offerings. Moody's would downgrade the bonds "should Debt to EBITDA remain above 3.25x." If you factor in AMZN's operating lease obligations, the leverage is already at 3.2x. (Debt+op lease obligations)/(EBITDA +rent expense) It's amazing to see an investment grade rating on an issuer leveraged over 3x and a rating rationale based on future this and that. Just goes to show you; in the ratings world, you still get what you pay for. Nothing has changed at Moody's or S&P.

Message.Title: Another Reason to short AMZN
Message.Msg: Analysts have no idea what the earnings are going to be for AMZN next year. Short-term EPS spread is a measure of not only risk in a stock, but a measure of how well analysts as a whole understand the company through company transparency and the markets they serve. For a company with $110B market cap (22nd largest in the S&P500) and more than $60B in revenue, this company and its markets should be well understood. The reason for the large spread is that AMZN tells investors nothing and analysts are left to speculate. This has been a successful strategy for AMZN as the analysts are so blinded by the brilliance of Bezos that they imagine a better future than any pumping the company could do on its own. So AMZN continues to be vague and not answer q’s and they continue to get rewarded. Compare the spread of AMZN 2013 EPS vs the competition below. Their EPS spread is 4 to 9 times higher than their comp. Their EPS range for next year delivers a P/E range of 65 to 542 (even with the most optimistic assessment the FWD P/E is still 65). Because analysts cannot justify the P/E for next year, they go out to 2017 to look at EPS of $11 and state that the P/E is only 22 on those earnings. And they have a job? They are asking to me to base a stock price on 2017 EPS when the variance for 2013 is 186%? Even if they are right on 2017, do they expect me to pay 2012 dollars for a 2017 P/E? With a 2017 P/E of 22, a 2012 dollar is only worth $0.29. That means AMZN should be valued at $244*29% = $71 in 2012 $. Don’t tell me this spread is due to “investment” as all of the companies are investing heavily (more so than AMZN) – they are tech companies, they have to! GOOG: $42.24 (low) - $51.20 (high), Mean = $46.39 (-9% / + 10% vs. Mean), 19% spread EBAY: $2.29 (low) - $2.96 (high), Mean = $2.73 (-16% / +8% vs. Mean), 24% spread AAPL: $43.63 (low) - $68.69 (high), Mean = $57.95 (-25% / + 19% vs. Mean), 44% spread AMZN: $0.45 (low) - $3.73 (high), Mean = $1.76 (-74% / + 112% vs. Mean), 186% spread

Topic.Title: PJ -- GMCR

Message.Msg: PJ: You know I nailed the GMCR from both the short and long side (while other shorts were still arguing it would get crushed from contract manufacturing). I am a #$%$ trader, but I am usually right on the strategic position and evolution of cost structures. With respect to your earlier question, the bond offering itself is a sham. It's just another example of how/why our capital markets are damaging our country. With less than that amount of capital, GRPN could execute the transaction I alluded to last night and create enormous shareholder value that actually does create value through enhanced utilization of existing infrastructure/assets/capabilities/people. With Amazon, it will instead be used to build more (redundant in the macro sense) distribution facilities and fund share buybacks when the stock is trading at a 1% true FCF yield (even real EBITDA yield rather than "adjusted" is less than 3%)... Amazon is uniquely vulnerable to event risk, but it is more likely to suffer from a series of changes in the competitive landscape and gradual erosion of the economics. People (investors) rarely synthesize the collective effects of the micro changes. The emergent behavior of systems is often quite different than we expect. That's where I focus my investment thinking because algorithms cannot do it and very few investors do it... We'll see. Just stay LT and patient. Amazon is not going to grow into its valuation. It will get pressure from all sides (Google with shopping listings to aid traditional bricks and mortar, FB with direct to consumer from manufacturer, macro drivers that will alter the components of the TCO, etc)... Tecj

The reason for the large spread is that AMZN tells investors nothing and analysts are left to speculate. This has been a successful strategy for AMZN as the analysts are so blinded by the brilliance of Bezos that they imagine a better future than any pumping the company could do on its own. So AMZN continues to be vague and not answer q’s and they continue to get rewarded. Compare the spread of AMZN 2013 EPS vs the competition below. Their EPS spread is 4 to 9 times higher than their comp. Their EPS range for next year delivers a P/E range of 65 to 542 (even with the most optimistic assessment the FWD P/E is still 65). Because analysts cannot justify the P/E for next year, they go out to 2017 to look at EPS of $11 and state that the P/E is only 22 on those earnings. And they have a job? They are asking to me to base a stock price on 2017 EPS when the variance for 2013 is 186%? Even if they are right on 2017, do they expect me to pay 2012 dollars for a 2017 P/E? With a 2017 P/E of 22, a 2012 dollar is only worth $0.29. That means AMZN should be valued at $244*29% = $71 in 2012 $. Don’t tell me this spread is due to “investment” as all of the companies are investing heavily (more so than AMZN) – they are tech companies, they have to!

Topic.Title: 9000% GAINS on ATTD very soon,KROGER NOW GOING TO SELL "ATTD'S" PRODUCT.

Message.Msg: Attitude Drinks Announces the Addition of The Kroger Co. to Retail Portfolio Bob Hearn Added to Attitude's Sales Team Attitude Drinks (OTCBB:ATTD) (OTCQB:ATTD), an innovative beverage brand development company and creator of the Phase III(R) Recovery brand, today announced a sales authorization with The Kroger Co., an American retailer headquartered in Cincinnati, Ohio. Kroger is notably the largest grocery store chain in the country. This chain was recently named the 36th most reputable company in the country by Forbes Magazine. Kroger not only operates the stores carrying their name, but also is proud of the "nearly two dozen banners" representing the 'family of stores' that operate within the Kroger system, nationwide. Phase III(R) will be available in select grocery stores through Kroger in Alabama, Georgia, Tennessee, South Carolina and Kentucky. Specifically, these Kroger stores within the above mentioned states are located in the greater Huntsville area in northern Alabama, statewide within Georgia and Tennessee, as well as Columbia and Myrtle Beach, South Carolina. Phase III(R) will be available in the sports nutrition sections of the chain in these locations. Jack Shea, EVP of Sales for Attitude Drinks, commented, "The placement of Phase III(R) Recovery in the Sports Nutrition sections of Kroger supermarkets provides recognition of the brand's growing popularity." Additionally, Robert "Bob" A. Hearn Jr. recently joined Attitude as a Regional Sales Manager to represent Attitude Drinks throughout the southeast section of the country. The states included within his territory are Kentucky, Tennessee, Georgia, Alabama, North Carolina and South Carolina to date. A graduate of the University of Georgia, Bob was a developer of the Q Water brand and most recently, launched White Quartz Distribution, offering an innovative approach to combination pallet distribution as relates to freight with new beverages. "Recovery drinks are one of the beverage industry's hottest categories. Phase III(R) is a great product and I am very excited to be associated with the Attitude organization. My goal is to make real milk recovery readily available to consumers throughout the southeast," commented Bob Hearn, Regional Sales Manager at Attitude Drinks, Inc.

Topic.Title: Pumperz and baggiez, sybs got some bad newz

Message.Msg: The return will come through the volatility that is yet to come. I don't see a bull market. I see real companies preserving more value and gaining in RELATIVE terms. The entire point of financial repression is to reduce real returns below real growth (population+real productivity) and slowly work through the debt burden. Japan has been at it for decades. The sad truth is that the only truly viable path out is step change productivity through technology, likely food, energy and manufacturing/process technology (read nanotechnology across all three...). But, our completely f'd up capital markets reward investment in consumption rather than production. The disconnect between value creation and value capture has never been larger. It is completely unsustainable and ultimately the root of fragility in society. It is coming to an end... That is what I mean by a return to investing. I am just hoping for a stable transition (because path dependency is real and Sybs' dystopian future is certainly possible...).

Topic.Title: jeff the bozo...doesn't pay the small little guy

Message.Msg: Shopping and investing locally is an important part of the solution. Handing your money to Jeff so he can invest in an out of state "fulfilment center" which evades state taxes and thus increases your burden where you cannot escape (property taxes) is a mistake... I expect a big backlash against Amazon's practices from Calpers and all state pension funds -- ain the final analysis, Amazon is taking tax revenues from them. Local merchantspay taxes and support the local economies. In 2013, Amazon will face a massive brand hit as the public better understands the wealth transfer via tax evasion...

Topic.Title: jeff the bozo...doesn't pay the small little guy

Message.Msg: Buying and investing locally is a critical part of the solution to our problems. When you do so, the money gets recirculated in the local economy -- and increases the velocity of money because most locals in most economies have a higher marginal propensity to consume than Jeff Bezos and those that own Scamazon...That in turn leads to a real multiplier rather than a leakage to the system. Once state pension funds like Calpers truly understand that Amazon's "fulfilled by Amazon" model is really hurting them first and foremost -- not just via the direct effect of lost taxes, but the indirect effect via the multiplier effect of lower local monetary velocity -- Amazon will have one helluva shareholder and branding issue...

Topic.Title: Here's why you dont hear emphasis on the producer:

Message.Msg: The sad part is bad accounting led companies to outsource a lot of the most financially attractive items to produce -- the cash cows. Back in the day of standard cost accounting, we allocated cost by labor hours, even when the real cost drivers were CapEx etc. That led assigning higher production cost on high volume items than was the case in reality. We outsourced "simple" / high volume items because emerging markets could do it more "cheaply", but the CapEx related costs didn't do away, making us "less competitive" on the remaining product lines, in turn leading to more outsourcing... We became producers of the low volume, high mix intensive product portfolio. We screwed ourselves trying to save the last dime and instead undermined our own cost competitiveness in many areas by taking on the higher relative overhead product portfolios... Having said that, we absolutely can compete, despite the incessant brainwashing to the contrary by WS (most of whom have never been in a plant that manufactures anything). Domestic chemicals manufacturers will be well positioned because of low natural gas prices. Intel still does kick everyone's butt (and will do so even more in the future as flows come into balance)... Shipping cost is going to continue growing as a share of the TCO (a significant reason I am short AMZN) of products and as it does, the balance will shift toward domestic production again... I really wish institutional longs would do the right thing and just sell through this... It only undermines trust in the market when they let predatory stop hunting algo funds squeeze shorts or put buyers, just like the long side. Stocks being valued on how they trade (function of float manipulation) rather than the value the companies create and capture (fundamentals) is what is ultimately chasing retail investors from the market... Benny B isn't the cause. The same short term mindset on WS that undermined our manufacturing base is... Having said that, I have complete conviction that Amazon will see 125 within a year and am prepared to ride through whatever comes my way between now and then... Now back to your regularly scheduled pumper taunting...
